title: Egg decorating
text:
Egg decorating is the art or craft of decorating <a href="egg%20%28food%29">egg</a>s. It has been a popular art form throughout history because of the attractive, smooth, oval shape of the egg, and the ancient associations with eggs as a religious and cultural symbol. Egg decorating has been associated with <a href="Easter">Easter</a> in recent times, but was practiced independently by many ancient cultures.
History.
Eggs are an important symbol in folklore and mythology, often representing life and rebirth, healing and protection, and sometimes featuring in creation myths. This means that traditional egg decorating existed throughout the world.
Africa.
The oldest eggshells, decorated with engraved hatched patterns, are dated for 60,000 years ago and were found at <a href="Diepkloof%20Rock%20Shelter">Diepkloof Rock Shelter</a> in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>.
In <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, it is a tradition to decorate boiled eggs during <a href="Sham%20el-Nessim">Sham el-Nessim</a>, a spring-ushering national holiday celebrated by Egyptians regardless of religion, which falls every year on the Monday following the <a href="Eastern%20Christianity">Eastern Christian</a> <a href="Easter">Easter</a>.
Australia.
In Australia, emu eggs are carved and the art created by them is known as <a href="kalti%20paarti%20carving">kalti paarti carving</a>. The art (which dates to the nineteenth century) is practised by people of different cultures, but it is associated most strongly with <a href="Indigenous%20Australian%20art">Aboriginal art</a>.
Eurasia.
A <a href="Ancient%20Carthage">Punic</a> ostrich egg was found in <a href="Villaricos">Villaricos</a>, Spain.
<a href="Orthodoxy%23Christianity">Orthodox Christians</a> in Mesopotamia used red dyed eggs to symbolise the <a href="blood%20of%20Christ">blood of Christ</a>, which is a possible origin of the <a href="Easter%20egg">Easter egg</a>. Red eggs feature in Greek Easter celebrations, where people play games which involve tapping the red eggs against each other.
<a href="Persian%20culture">Persian culture</a> has a tradition of egg decorating, which takes place during the spring <a href="equinox">equinox</a>. This time marks <a href="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, the Persian New Year. Family members decorate eggs together and place them in a bowl. It is said that it is from this cultural tradition that the Christian practice on Easter ultimately originates, having been transmitted via the Slavs; long ago Slavic and Iranic peoples formed a close continuum sharing many traditions and innovations in religion and language and in the first millennium many formerly Iranic peoples would eventually become Turkic or Slavic in identity. The tradition of Nowruz, which has its roots in at least ancient <a href="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrian</a> tradition, is practised by Persian and <a href="Turkic%20peoples">Turkic</a> peoples of various faiths, albeit the tradition of egg decorating may be even older than the holiday as known modernly.
<a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern European</a> and <a href="North%20Asia">North Asian</a> cultures, particularly Slavic ones, have a strong tradition of <a href="Egg%20decorating%20in%20Slavic%20culture">decorating eggs</a> which date back at least to times when <a href="Slavic%20paganism">Slavic paganism</a> was the predominant religion. Chicken, duck and goose eggs are decorated variously with batik dyeing, applique, scratch-work, wax encaustic and carving. Egg decorating is particularly popular in Ukraine, where as in many Slavic countries, the eggs are called <a href="Pysanka">Pysanky</a>. The renowned <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n court artist and jeweller <a href="Peter%20Carl%20Faberg%C3%A9">Peter Carl Fabergé</a> made exquisitely decorated <a href="precious%20metal">precious metal</a> and <a href="gemstone">gemstone</a> eggs for the Romanovs. These <a href="Faberg%C3%A9%20egg">Fabergé egg</a>s resembled standard decorated eggs, but they were made from <a href="gold">gold</a> and precious stones. In addition to the Slavs, many <a href="Turkic%20peoples">Turkic</a> peoples also maintain closely-related traditions of egg dying, associated with the coming of Spring and the Persian New Year <a href="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>.
In many parts of Europe, egg decorating took place before the widespread adoption of <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a>, so it is unclear to what extent <a href="paganism">paganism</a> and Christianity influenced the practice. The earliest example of egg decoration in Europe was a decorated egg found buried with a Slavic girl in modern-day <a href="Worms%2C%20Germany">Worms</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, dating to the 5th century, when eggs were not yet associated with <a href="Easter">Easter</a>. This was near the beginning of the <a href="Slavic%20migrations">Slavic migrations</a> into Europe. <a href="Slavic%20paganism">Slavic paganism</a> had ties to other early Eastern Indo-European religions such as old Persian religions, albeit often with peculiar influence from neighbouring <a href="Finnic%20peoples">Finnic peoples</a> as well. 
In <a href="Northern%20England">Northern England</a>, the tradition of <a href="Pace%20Egg%20play">Pace Egging</a> (derived from <a href="Latin">Latin</a> "pascha" meaning 'Easter') involved boiling eggs in onion skins to dye their shells a golden colour, or alternatively covered in leaves or flowers inside an onion skin to leave a patterned imprint. The tradition is practiced on <a href="Easter">Easter</a> but is thought to be pre-Christian in origin. <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavian</a> traditions also involved boiling eggs with flowers inside onion skins to colour them.
Another type of egg decoration is the <a href="Hungary">Hungarian</a> practice of <a href="egg%20shoeing">egg shoeing</a>, which requires goose eggs and miniature horse-shoes, made of iron or lead. The current world record of egg shoeing is 1119 shoes on a single ostrich egg.
Techniques and modern practices.
Any <a href="bird%20egg">bird egg</a> can be facilitated in this process, but most often the larger and stronger the eggshell is, the more favoured it will be by decorators.
<a href="Goose">Goose</a>, <a href="duck">duck</a> and <a href="Chicken">hen</a>s' eggs are usually "blown" – a hole is made in each end and the contents are blown out. The egg is then either carved, dyed, painted, appliqued or otherwise decorated (using a number of different techniques). Egg decoration is particularly popular in Eastern European countries.
Some eggs, like <a href="emu">emu</a> or <a href="ostrich%20egg">ostrich egg</a>s, are so large and strong that the shells may be carved without breaking. Decorations on emu eggs take advantage of the contrast in colours between the dark green mottled outside of the shell and the shell-underlay. 
Many modern egg artists decorate their "art eggs" by etching or carving, while others paint or cover their eggs with different materials, from paper and fabric to <a href="polymer%20clay">polymer clay</a> and are often painted in bright, spring colours. Using eggs as a canvas has become so popular that special terms have developed with the art form. Egg artists also have their own guild, the International Egg Art Guild, which promotes the craft of egg artistry.
In the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> there are shows in many states where artists show their eggs and vendors of "egging" supplies can be found. Each year, the <a href="White%20House">White House</a> chooses a decorated egg from each state to display at <a href="easter">easter</a>.
